abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector
            Development Program of Mali were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, the Bank performance was unsatisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: First, the moderately
            unsatisfactory rating of this project is mostly due to the
            establishment of overambitious targets. Once again,
            over-promising proves not to be a good strategy. Second,
            whatever the financial instrument (investment project,
            program support, or other), there is no substitute for
            conducting the analytical work, which is essential for
            avoiding major design flaws. In this case, the lack of
            in-depth analytical work might explain why PDOs and many
            intermediate objectives were not discussed realistically.
            Third, though often agreed on in haste, the modalities for
            entering into and transitioning from program arrangements
            are complex and require careful study. Fourth, project
            preparation must reach fundamental agreement on the
            determinants of health status; otherwise, as the MTR points
            out, funds are more likely to support activities which are
            easier to implement rather than those which are more
            difficult, but also more strategically important (e.g.,
            human resources) or more broadly linked with improved health
            status (nutrition, water and hygiene, literacy, etc.).
            Fifth, implementation of health sector support is easier
            when health sector decentralization (or at least
            de-concentration) is ahead of overall administrative decentralization.

repnme.cdata!: Mali - Health Sector Development Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Development Program
            Project's objective is to improve the health outcome of
            the population, with a focus on meeting the health needs of
            the underserved segments of the population, as well as
            accelerating the country's demographic transition
            toward slower population growth. There are three project
            components. The first component, expanding access to
            affordable quality preventive, social, and curative
            services, will improve coverage for primary health care;
            improve services in selected secondary and tertiary
            hospitals; improve overall technical efficiency, increase
            initial stocks of drugs and medical consumable; and provide
            support to nongovernmental organizations for health-related
            activities and action against social exclusion. The second
            component, strengthening the health system management
            capabilities, will cover management training; recruitment
            and redeployment of health personnel; reforms of
            pharmaceutical sub-sector; logistic support for managerial
            functions; and support to the Management Information
            Systems. The third component, exploring and developing
            sustainable financing schemes for the health sector, will be
            done through expansion of cooperative cost sharing schemes;
            policy reforms on benefits; community participation; and
            cost recovery mechanism.
